name: Super TV-Boy
power: 4 AA batteries or 6V DC (positive tip) external PSU
description:
Last child of its family, the Super TV-Boy (aka TV-Boy III) is basically an Atari 2600 clone, embedding 127 games which actually are pirate renamed versions of old Atari games. With its new design and its detachable control pad, the Super TV-Boy may be considered as a DeLuxe version of the well known TV-Boy.

This cheap system was made in asia and sold in Europe by the french company Akor and is definitely rarer than its predecessor and its numerous clones. The system uses a bank switching technique and the 127 built-in games are accessed via an on-screen menu (the 128th program) so there is no dip switch as seen on some pirate x-in-one cartridges. This menu (that seems to be located at the lowest address of the ROM) is executed by default when the system starts and once a game is selected, there is no mean to come back, so one needs to restart the system to play another game.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DETACHABLE CONTROL PAD</strong></font><br><blockquote>A small but handy control pad</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIDE VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Only two connectors : composite video cable (SCART) and external PSU. The Super TV-Boy lacks the Atari joystick connectors existing on older versions (TV-Boy)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHER BOARD CLOSE-UP (SOLDER SIDE)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This close-up picture shows the bord revision number (the TV-Boy II board is labelled "WS-11FT")</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHER BOARD CLOSE-UP (COMPONENTS SIDE)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This close-up shows the real name of this system : TV-Boy III</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> A DIFFERENT VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In april 2001, Firebox, a UK based company released a new version of the Super TV-Boy, with a very different design but the same specifications.<p class="petitgris">www.firebox.com</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER NOTES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This fanzine - one of the first of the microcomputers era - was published by the Altair User Group<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> WONDER COMPUTE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under all pictures of the promotional guide, you can read : "all screenshots are real and have not been retouched". <br><br> Really?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... One of the results is our new identity and our new product: the Intersystems DPS-1. An IEEE S-100 compatible mainframe with features that live up to its look. <i>Dependable</i> operation to 4 Mhz. Twenty-card capacity, a modular power supply. And something no one else has: built-in break points to give you a faster, more powerful tool for testing software as well as hardware...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-503 is a YIS-303 with more memory (32 kb) and a proper keyboard.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''It's time''<br> ''ATMOS from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT   </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font>  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to its optional modem, the TO-7/70 could be connected to the Teletel communication network. This skilled photograph is browsing the Liberation (popular french newspaper) site. <br><br> But there are still no cables shown here ! How the whole system is running ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>In July 1985, California Digital sold the Tano at $99. The price would decrease down to $35 while stock last.</blockquote>

emulator.name: Stella
emulator.description: Stella is a very good multi-platform Atari 2600 VCS emulator and has alredy been ported to AcornOS, AmigaOS, DOS, FreeBSD, IRIX, Linux, OS/2, MacOS, Unix, and Windows.
